sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are Vasanta (spring), Grishma (summer), and Varsha (monsoon); these two, the Devas (gods), are Sharat (autumn) and Hemanta (late autumn); and those are the Pittaras (ancestors), the cool season Sisira.

sloka: yavāgūrodano dadhi samigrāmakāmānnādyakāmendriyakāmatejaskāmānāṃ
translation: The tears of the one who is fond of worldly pleasures and desires milk.

sloka: tadyatheṣīkātūlamagnau protaṃ pradūyetaiv~ hāsya sarve pāpmānaḥ pradūyante ya etadevaṃ vidvānagnihotraṃ juhoti ||
translation: The one who knows this (the firewood) made of the dry sacred fig tree, at first laughs off (the idea), but once he comes to understand (the true significance), all sinful people denounce him. He who performs the agnihotra (fire sacrifice) knowing this.

sloka: yatheha kṣudhitā bālā mātaraṃ paryupāsate | ev~ sarvāṇi bhūtānyagnihotramupāsata ityagnihotramupāsata iti ||
translation: In the same way that a hungry child serves his mother, one should worship all beings as Agnihotra. (This is the repeated instruction.)

sloka: agnayo vai trayī vidyā devayānaḥ panthā gārhapatya ṛk pṛthivī rathantaramanvāhāryapacanaḥ yajurantarikṣaṃ vāmadevyamāhavanīyaḥ sāma suvargo loko bṛhattasmādagnīn paramaṃ vadanti || ||
translation: The threefold knowledge is called Agni's path, the fire of the household is Ṛk, the earth is the fuel carrier, while Manavantara-Rathantara is the oblation for the air, and Vāmadeva is the oblation for the sky. They say that the Sāma is the way to heaven, hence Agni is considered supreme.

sloka: agnihotra~ sāyaṃ prātargṛhāṇāṃ niṣkṛtiḥ sviṣṭa~ suhutaṃ yajñakratūnāṃ prāyaṇa~ suvargasya lokasya jyotistasmādagnihotra~ paramaṃ vadanti ||
translation: The twilight oblation is called the finest because it marks the end of the rituals of the household fires and is the illumination for the path to heaven for those who perform sacrifices .

sloka: vasanti prāṇino yatra |
translation: Where living beings reside.

sloka: tataḥ tu irāvatīm nāma jajñe bhadramadā sutām | tasyāḥ tu airāvataḥ putro lokanātho mahāgajaḥ ||
translation: Then was born Irāvatī, Bhadra's daughter. Her son was Airāvata, the protector of the world, a great elephant.

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ | tasya kartāramapi māṃ viddhyakartāramavyayam ||
translation: I, as the creator, have established the four-varnas based on qualities and actions. Understand me to be the eternal doer and non-doer of this.

sloka: eṣāmutpattyādiryathā yadā bhagavān puruṣarūpeṇa sṛṣṭiṃ kṛtavān tadāsyaśarīrāt catvāro varṇā utpannāḥ mukhato brāhmaṇāḥ bāhutaḥ kṣatriyāḥ ūruto vaiśyāḥ pādataḥ śūdrā jātāḥ
translation: When the Lord in his cosmic form brought about creation, then from him emerged, in order, four varnas (social classes) from his mouth were the brahmins, from his arms the kshatriyas, from his thighs the vaishyas, and from his feet the shudras.

sloka: brāhmaṇo'sya mukhamāsīdbāhū rājanyaḥ kṛtaḥ | ūrū tadasya yadvaiśyaḥ padbhyāṃ śūdro ajāyata ||
translation: The mouth belonged to the brahmana, his arms to the king, his thighs to the vaisya, and from his feet the shudra was born.

sloka: āśramaḥ śāstrokta dharmmaviśeṣaḥ| āśrāmyanti svaṃ svaṃ tapaścarantyatra | sa caturvidhaḥ | brahmacaryyaṃ gārhasthyaṃ vānaprasthyaṃ sannyāsaḥ | iti smṛtiḥ || brahmacārī | gṛhī | vānaprasthaḥ | bhikṣuḥ | ityamaraḥ ||
translation: The āśrama, as described in scriptures, is a fourfold observance - brahmacharya, gārhastyam, vānaprasthya, and sannyāsa. In their respective stages of life, individuals pursue (tap) their own duties therein. This is the teaching of smṛiti. The stages are: brahmacārī, gṛhī, vānaprastha, and bhikṣu.

sloka: trayo dharmaskandhā yajño'dhyayanaṃ dānamiti prathamastapa eva dvitīyo brahmacāryācāryakulavāsī tṛtīyo'tyantamātmānamācāryakule'vasādayansarva ete puṇyalokā bhavanti brahmasa~stho'mṛtatvameti || ||
translation: The three pillars of dharma are sacrifice, study, and charity; the second is living in the guru's household as a student, the third is realizing the self while residing in the guru's house. All these lead to spiritual worlds and immortality, for one who is established in brahman.

sloka: yathā vāyuṃ samāśritya vartante sarvajantavaḥ | tathā gṛhasthaṃ āśritya vartante sarva āśramāḥ | | | | yasmāttrayo'pyāśramiṇo jñānenānnena cānvaham | gṛhasthenaiva dhāryante tasmājjyeṣṭhāśramo gṛhī | | | |
translation: Just as all living beings flourish by taking shelter in the wind, similarly all asramas (stages of life) flourish by taking shelter in the grihastha (householder). Indeed, the knowledge and sustenance for the three other asramis come from the grihastha alone. Therefore, the most excellent asrama is the grihasthashrama.

sloka: ṛgvedaṃ bhagavo'dhyemi yajurveda~ sāmavedamātharvaṇaṃ caturthamitihāsapurāṇaṃ pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vedaṃ pitrya~ rāśiṃ daivaṃ nidhiṃ vākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyāṃ brahmavidyāṃ bhūtavidyāṃ kṣatravidyāṃ nakṣatravidyāṃ sarpadevajñavidyāmetadbhagavo'dhyemi
translation: I study ṛgveda, bhagavan, as well as yajurveda, sāmaveda, and the fourth, atharvaṇa; I also study the fifth vedānām, called veda, which is pitrya, rāśi, daiva, nidhi, vaak-vākya, ekāyana; I study in it deva-vidya, brahma-vidya, bhūta-vidya, kṣatra-vidya, nakṣatra-vidya, and sarpadeva-jñavidya - all this, bhagavan, I study.

sloka: so'haṃ bhagavo mantravidevāsmi nā''tmavicchuta~hyeva me bhagavoddṛśebhyastarati śokamātmaviditi so'haṃ bhagavaḥ śocāmi taṃ mā bhagavā ñchokasya parāṃ tārayatviti ta~hovāca yadvai kiṃcaitadadhyagīṣṭhānāmaivaitat
translation: I am indeed he, the lord, who knows the mantras. He does not depart from me, and my lord, it is you who should dispel the grief of those similar to you, as you know the self. Therefore, he said, "this is indeed the foremost name."

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda atharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśidaivo nidhirvākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyā brahmavidyā bhūtavidyā kṣatravidyā nakṣatravidyā sarpadevajñavidyā nāmaivaitannāmopāssveti
translation: The Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvana are indeed the first four Vedas, while the Itihasa-Puranas is the fifth. This is the teaching of the pitrs (ancestors) and the rishis (sages). It is the treasury of knowledge about dharma, gods, brahman, elements, kshatra, nakshatras, and serpent deities. I indeed meditate upon this name. You two also should meditate upon it. Learn it in this way.

sloka: yadā vai vijānātyatha satyaṃ vadati nāvijānansatyaṃ vadati vijānanneva satyaṃ vadati vijñānaṃ tveva vijijñāsitavyamiti vijñānaṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When you correctly understand what is true and speak it, or when, not understanding, you do not speak what is true, but rather come to understand and then speak what is true – such comprehensively knowing must be sought after, Bhagavan. You should desire to thoroughly inquire into this.

sloka: yadā vai manute'tha vijānāti nāmatvā vijānāti matvaiva vijānāti matistveva vijijñāsitavyeti matiṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one truly comprehends, "This is the named (self)"), only then does it become necessary to inquire into the mind. Thus, O Bhagavan, you should investigate your own mind.

sloka: yadā vai śraddadhātyatha manute nāśraddadhanmanute śraddadheva manute śraddhātveva vijijñāsitavyeti śraddhāṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one has faith and ponders upon it, not lacking in faith, but having faith, they should investigate. "Please inquire about faith," thus (the teacher) says.

sloka: yadā vai nistiṣṭhatyatha śraddadhāti nānistiṣṭhacchraddadhāti nistiṣṭhanneva śraddadhāti niṣṭhātveva vijijñāsitavyeti niṣṭhāṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one fully commits and has firm faith, or lacks commitment yet pretends to have faith, it is the commitment that must be carefully investigated, Bhagavan. Only then should one seek to understand the nature of true commitment.

sloka: yadā vai karotyatha nistiṣṭhati nākṛtvā nistiṣṭhati kṛtvaiva nistiṣṭhati kṛtistveva vijijñāsitavyeti kṛtiṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When should one establish (themselves) having done it or not, Bhagavan has asked to inquire about the action's nature.

sloka: yadā vai sukhaṃ labhate'tha karoti nāsukhaṃ labdhvā karoti sukhameva labdhvā karoti sukhaṃ tveva vijijñāsitavyamiti sukhaṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one acquires happiness, they should act in a way that does not cause suffering. Once happiness is gained, one should act to maintain that happiness. This is what ought to be thoroughly understood, says the blessed one: "May I have the desire to examine (this)".

sloka: vedam evābhyasennityaṃ yathākām atandritaḥ | taṃ hyasyāhuḥ paraṃ dharmam upadharmo'nya ucyate
translation: One should regularly and passionately study the Veda in this way. Indeed, they say that is the supreme duty; anything else is declared to be contrary to duty.

sloka: vayasaḥ karmaṇo'rthasya śrutasyābhijanasya ca | veṣavāgbuddhisārūpyaṃ ācaranvicarediha śrutismṛtyuditaṃ samyaṅnibaddhaṃ sveṣu karmasu | dharmamūlaṃ niṣeveta sadācāraṃ atandritaḥ ācārāllabhate hyāyurācārādīpsitāḥ prajāḥ | ācārāddhanaṃ akṣayyaṃ ācāro hantyalakṣaṇam
translation: Of a bird's actions and the purpose of hearing and lineage , what has been previously taught about their resemblance in speech and intellect , you should strictly follow that as the root of righteousness when engaged in activities . In your own actions, be unwavering , for long life and desired offspring come from proper conduct . Conduct is the means to wealth that never diminishes , and it also indicates when something must be stopped .

sloka: kaṇādena tu saṃproktaṃ śāstraṃ vaiśeṣikaṃ mahat | gautamena tathā nyāyaṃ sāṃkhyaṃ tu kapilena vai ||
translation: Kaṇāda, so spoken of, the distinguished Vaiśeṣika śāstra; and Gautama, the Nyāya - all praised by Kapila, the Sāṃkhya.

sloka: saḥ eṣaḥ saptabhiḥ puruṣairnipaṉna ekaḥ puruṣaḥ prajāpatiḥ virāṭ abhūt evaṃ liṅgaśarīrābhimānihiraṇyagarbhakartṛkā virāḍutpattiruktā tasya virājo'gnirūpatāmāha sa yaḥ puruṣaḥ iti sa prajāpatiḥ eva ayaṃ cīyamānaḥ agniḥ ityarthaḥ kāṇḍikā atha yo garbho'ntarāsīt so'gnirasṛjyata sa yadasya sarvasyāgramasṛjyata tasmādagniḥ agnirhavai tamagnirityācakṣate paro'kṣam paro'kṣakāmā hi devāḥ kāṇḍikā
translation: This very Purusha, produced by seven Purushas, is indeed the single Purusha, Prajapati and Virat. Thus is described the emergence of his form-body. The one who is called 'Purusha' is indeed Prajapati. This actively blazing fire here is that very same one. As for what was inside as a embryo, that became this fire; when he produced all the seeds, therefore he is called 'Fire'. The Fire, who is beyond sight and beyond desire, is thus proclaimed by the wise ones.

sloka: medhāyai manase'gnaye svāheti medhayā vai manasābhigacchati yajeyeti tadasyetadamubhayamātmanyeva yanmedhā ca manaśca te asminnete ubhe devate ātmanyādhīte
translation: To wisdom, mind, and fire, one offers "svāhā" with a focused mind; similarly, one should approach the other two— meditation and sacrifice—in this way. For, both meditation and mind are, in essence, that same wisdom; they are not different from it. And indeed, those who understand this consider both these things to be residing within their own self.

sloka: sa tvamagniṃ svargyamadhyeṣi mṛtyo prabrūhi tvaṃ śraddadhānāya mahyam | svargalokā amṛtatvaṃ bhajanta etad dvitīyena vṛṇe vareṇa || ||
translation: You, as the revered one in heaven, point out to me the fire. Reveal this to me, the faithful one. Here, in these two realms of heaven, immortality is sought after through your choice.

sloka: atha hāgnaya: samūdire tapto brahmacārī kuśalaṃ na: paryacārīddhantāsmai prabravāmeti tasmai hocu: || ||
translation: "Now, having completed the austerities, oh Hagnis, shall we respectfully address this excellent brahmachari? To him let us say, 'May you skillfully accomplish your purpose.' Thus they praised him."

sloka: atha hainaṃ gārhapatyo'nu śaśāsa pṛthivyagnirannamāditya iti ya | eṣa āditye puruṣo dṛśyate so'hamasmi sa evāhamasmīti || ||
translation: "Then the householder commanded him, 'Worship the fire of the earth with offerings, as Āditya (the sun) does.' The one who is seen in the Āditya (sun) is me; I am truly that one."

sloka: yadā lelāyate hṛārci: samiddhe havyavāhane tadājyabhāgāvantareṇāhutī: pratipādayet
translation: When the sacrificial fire is kindled, then (tadā) should (pratipādayet) the offerer establish the oblations in the middle of the portion of ghee and the oblation. (Here, havyavāhane refers to the sacrificial fire, hṛ_ārciḥ is the flame of the sacrificial fire, samiddhe is the state of being kindled, ājya is the ghee offered in the sacrifice, bhāgau are the two portions of ghee and oblation, antareṇa is the middle, and āhutīḥ are the oblations).

sloka: kālī karālī ca manojavā ca sulohitā yā ca sudhūmravarṇā sphuliṅginīṃ viśvarucī ca devī lelāyamānā iti sapta jihvā:
translation: The seven tongues, namely Kali, Karali, Manojava, Sulohita, Sudhumravarna, Sphulingini, and Visvaruci, flickering.

sloka: śākalyaseya śataṃ śiṣyā naiṣṭhikabrahmacāriṇaḥ pañca teṣāṃ gṛhasthāste dharmaniṣṭhāśca kuṭumbinaḥ śiśiro vāṣkalo sāṃkhyo vātsyaścaivāśvalāyanaḥ pañcaite śākalāḥ śiṣyāḥ śākhābhedapravarttakāḥ
translation: In the future, these five disciples of the Śākalyas, namely the steadfast celibate brahmin follower, the householder firm in his duties, the one who adheres to Sāṃkhya philosophy, Vātsya, and Āśvalāyana, will become two - Śiśira and Vāṣkala; these five disciples are the originators of the branch divisions.

sloka: ijyate'neneti yajuḥ
translation: The Yajus is being performed using this.

sloka: aniyatākṣarāvasāno yajuḥ ||
translation: The Yajus ritual text, with its unrepeated (and hence, individually unspecified) syllables, is named.

sloka: gadyātmako yajuḥ
translation: The essence of Yajus hymns.

sloka: ādityānīmāni śuklāni yajūṃṣi vājasaneyena yājñavalkyenākhyāyante
translation: These white (śuklāni) yajus hymns, named 'Vājasaneya' and 'Yājñavalkya,' are being recited/designated as pertaining to the Ādityas.

sloka: sā cāmaśceti tatsāmnaḥ sāmatvam |
translation: She, along with āma, embodies equality. This oneness is the nature of that (sāmnaḥ).

sloka: vedānāṃ sāmavedosmi |
translation: I am the Rigveda among the Vedas.

sloka: ‘karmacodanā brāhmaṇāni
translation: The brahmana texts that incite to action.

sloka: araṇye'dhīyūrān
translation: The two had been admitted into seclusion . Those who were to be taught are the ones taking part in the act of learning .

sloka: vaiśvānaraḥ praviśati atithirbrāhmaṇo gṛhān | tasyaitā~ śāntiṃ kurvanti hara vaivasvatodakam || ||
translation: The all-pervading fire called Vaishvanara enters the house of a Brahmin as a noble guest. They make him peaceful by offering the oblation to the fire-god, Vasuva.

sloka: āśāpratīkṣe saṅgata~ sūnṛtāṃ ca iṣṭāpūrte putrapaśū~śca sarvān | etadvṛṅkte puruṣasyālpamedhaso yasyānaśnanvasati brāhmaṇo gṛhe || ||
translation: The man of meager intelligence incapacitates all--the hope, the friendly meeting, the pleasant speech, and the desired prosperity of his son and cattle--who dwells in the house of a Brahmin without partaking.

sloka: ki~svidyamasya kartavyaṃ yanmayā'dya kariṣyati || ||
translation: What is the task that I should accomplish today?

sloka: śāntasaṅkalpaḥ sumanā yathā syādvītamanyurgautamo mābhimṛtyo | tvatprasṛṣṭaṃ mā'bhivadetpratīta etat trayāṇāṃ prathama varaṃ vṛṇe || ||
translation: Just as a contented resolve and tranquility are conducive, may Gautama also be freed from anger; I choose the foremost of the three - the one who has been sent forth (by you) and is recognized.

sloka: yathā purastādbhavitā pratīta auddālakirāruṇirmatprasṛṣṭaḥ | sukha~ rātrīḥ śayitā vītamanyuḥ tvāṃ dadṛśivānmṛtyumukhāt pramuktam || ||
translation: Just as the reddish-tinged Uddalaka, known for his creation, was seen, lying on a bed of happiness, free from anger during the peaceful nights, so have I seen you released from the jaws of death.

sloka: svarge loke na bhayaṃ kiñcanāsti na tatra tvaṃ na jarayā bibheti | ubhe tīrtvā aśanāyāpipāse śokātigo modate svargaloke || ||
translation: In heaven, there is no fear whatsoever; neither should you fear there nor aging. Having crossed over both hunger and thirst, as well as grief, one delights in the abode of heaven.

sloka: sa tvamagni~ svargyamadhyeṣi mṛtyo prabrūhi tva~ śraddadhānāya mahyam | svargalokā amṛtatvaṃ bhajanta etad dvitīyena vṛṇe vareṇa || ||
translation: You, as the fire, exist in the abode of heaven; speak to me who is devoted. They enjoy immortality in the heavenly world; I choose this as the second preference.

sloka: prate bravīmi tadu me nibodha svargyamagniṃ naciketaḥ prajānan | anantalokāptimatho pratiṣṭhāṃ viddhi tvametaṃ nihitaṃ guhāyām || ||
translation: I declare in the presence of Fire, O Nachiketa, come to know this Agni as leading to svargaloka and infinite prosperity, and as the firm basis of support. You should understand this truth, placed hidden in it.

sloka: lokādimagniṃ tamuvāca tasmai yā iṣṭakā yāvatīrvā yathā vā | sa cāpi tatpratyavadadyathoktaṃ athāsya mṛtyuḥ punarevāha tuṣṭaḥ || ||
translation: The foremost in the world, having addressed him, spoke to him: "Whatever favors you wish to grant, do as you have said." Then, his death satisfied, came again.

sloka: tamabravītprīyamāṇo mahātmā varaṃ tavehādya dadāmi bhūyaḥ | tavaiva nāmnā bhavitāyamagniḥ sṛṅkāṃ cemāmanekarūpāṃ gṛhāṇa || ||
translation: The noble one, pleased, said to him: "I give you an additional boon today. Let this fire be known by your name. Take hold of this variously shaped (offering)."

sloka: yeyaṃ prete vicikitsā manuṣye astītyeke nāyamastīti caike | etadvidyāmanuśiṣṭastvayā'haṃ varāṇāmeṣa varastṛtīyaḥ || ||
translation: Of the two opinions in people about whether this doubt exists after death or not, one group says it does, while another denies its existence. This is the established conclusion ; through your guidance, I , among all noble paths , have chosen this one as my third .

sloka: devairatrāpi vicikitsitaṃ purā na hi suvijñeyamaṇureṣa dharmaḥ | anyaṃ varaṃ naciketo vṛṇīṣva mā moparotsīrati mā sṛjainam || ||
translation: Even the gods have found it (the proper duty) difficult to determine in the past. Therefore, Naciketa, choose another, more desirable, path. Don't let yourself be deluded, and don't create (more) confusion.

sloka: devairatrāpi vicikitsitaṃ kila tvaṃ ca mṛtyo yanna sujñeyamāttha | vaktā cāsya tvādṛganyo na labhyo nānyo varastulya etasya kaścit || ||
translation: By the gods has it indeed been doubted, and even by you, O mortal, what is not easily known. A revealer of this matter like you is not to be found, nor another equal to him in excellence. Is there perhaps anyone who can obtain him?

sloka: yasminnidaṃ vicikitsanti mṛtyo yatsāmparāye mahati brūhi nastat | yo'yaṃ varo gūḍhamanupraviṣṭo nānyaṃ tasmānnaciketā vṛṇīte || ||
translation: In which is this being doubted , regarding great death in the future , tell us . That fortune which has secretly entered should not be chosen by Naciketā , for that reason .

sloka: naiva vācā na manasā prāptuṃ śakyo na cakṣuṣā | astīti bruvato'nyatra kathaṃ tadupalabhyate || ||
translation: It cannot be grasped by speech, mind, or sight, they say. But how can it be experienced if not mentioned? Such is its mysterious nature.

sloka: astītyevopalabdhavyastattvabhāvena cobhayoḥ | astītyevopalabdhasya tattvabhāvaḥ prasīdati || ||
translation: The true nature of both "you have found" and "it is" becomes clear when it is seen that "you have found" is the future passive participle and "it is" is the third-person singular present indicative.

sloka: yadā sarve pramucyante kāmā ye'sya hṛdi śritāḥ | atha martyo'mṛto bhavatyatra brahma samaśnute || ||
translation: When all desires that are dwelling in his heart are completely abandoned, then the mortal becomes immortal, he attains Brahman at that moment.

sloka: etaddhyevākṣaraṃ brahma etaddhyevākṣaraṃ param | etaddhyevākṣaraṃ jñātvā yo yadicchati tasya tat || ||
translation: This syllable alone is Brahman, this alone is the supreme. Having known this syllable, one's desires are fulfilled.

sloka: aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ puruṣo'ntarātmā sadā janānāṃ hṛdaye saṃniviṣṭaḥ | taṃ svāccharīrātpravṛhenmuñjādiveṣīkāṃ dhairyeṇa | taṃ vidyācchukramamṛtaṃ taṃ vidyācchukramamṛtamiti || ||
translation: The being, measuring just a thumb's width, dwells continually in the hearts of all. One may perceive him, having emerged from one's own physical self and the coverings of senses and mind, through the utmost concentration and insight. He is subtle, immortal; indeed, he is that immortal.

sloka: triṇāciketastribhiretya sandhiṃ trikarmakṛttarati janmamṛtyū | brahmajajñaṃ devamīḍyaṃ viditvā nicāyya mā~ śāntimatyantameti || ||
translation: Having understood the fire-god, who has knowledge of Brahman and is brilliant, as having three footprints and being a performer of three actions, Triṇāciketa transcends the cycle of birth and death. Do not miss achieving the ultimate peace.

sloka: triṇāciketastrayametadviditvā ya evaṃ vidvā~ ścinute nāciketam | sa mṛtyupāśānpurataḥ praṇodya śokātigo modate svargaloke || ||
translation: Having understood the three-questioned fire sacrifice and becoming thus wise, one who delights in learning about it, such a one, freed from the fear of death, experiences unalloyed happiness in the heavenly world.

sloka: pratigrahasamartho'pi prasaṅgaṃ tatra varjayet | pratigraheṇa hyasyāśu brāhmaṃ tejaḥ praśāmyati naitādṛśaḥ paro dharmo nṛṇāṃ saddharmamicchatām nyāso daṇḍasya bhūteṣu manovākkāyajasya yaḥ
translation: Even if capable, one should avoid the engagement of acceptance there. For, it quickly calms the Brahmanical power within him; this is not a righteous behavior for humans seeking to establish dharma in their mind, speech, and body towards others.

sloka: yathā candraśca rohiṇyāmurmilāyāṃ dhaneśvaraḥ|| yatra rājā vaivasvato yatrāvarodhanaṃ divaḥ yatrāmūryahvatīrāpastatra māmamṛtaṃ kṛdhīndrāyendo pari srava
translation: Like the moon merging with Rohini, just as the lord of riches (Indra) desired in the past, when King Vaivasvata and Amurya-Vatira are present, there make me, the immortal nectar, yours, Indrāyendu. O Srava, listen carefully.

sloka: tisro dyāvaḥ savitura dvā upasthāṃ ekā yamasya bhuvane virāṣāṭa āṇiṃ na rathyamamṛtādhi tasthuriha bravītu ya u tacciketat
translation: Of the heavenly bodies, which three did Savitar cause to approach a single abode in Yama's world, not easily passed beyond, an imperishable support? Let him declare it here. Who knows this, knows Tacciketat.

sloka: naciketamupākhyānaṃ mṛtyuproktaṃ sanātanam
translation: The timeless narrative known as "Naciketa" has been spoken about by Death.

sloka: aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ puruṣo'ntarātmā sadā janānāṃ hṛdaye sanniviṣṭaḥ
translation: The self, equivalent in size to a thumb, is situated within the hearts of all people.

sloka: dharati lokān dhriyate puṇyātmabhiriti vā |
translation: The earth supports the worlds and is itself supported by the pure ātman (self, soul) through its actions.

sloka: janmanā brāhmaṇo jñeyaḥ saṃskārairdvija ucyate vidyayā yāti vipratvaṃ tribhiḥ śrotriyalakṣaṇam iti prāyaścittavivekaḥ
translation: "A brahmin is to be known by birth; he is called 'dvija' through sacred rites. By learning, he attains the state of a vipra. The marker of one who knows is distinguishing between expiatory actions, characterized by the threefold signs of a knower of the Vedas."

sloka: ākāśādvāyuḥ | vāyoragniḥ | agnerāpaḥ | adbhyaḥ pṛthivī ||| ||
translation: From space arises air, from air arises fire, from fire arises water, and from water arises earth.

sloka: dyaurme pitā janitā nābhiratra bandhurme mātā pṛthivī mahīyam |||
translation: Sky is my father, the nurturer; the navel-like center is my relation here; Earth is my mother, vast and this is she.

sloka: mātā bhūmiḥ putro'haṃ pṛthivyāḥ ||
translation: I am the son, and the earth is my mother.

sloka: yatte bhūme vikhanāmi kṣipraṃ tadapi rohatu | mā te marma vimṛgvari mā te hṛdayamarpipam ||
translation: "O earth, whatever I dig up quickly, let that also quickly grow back. May your vitality and heart never be fully understood or pierced through."

sloka: upasthāste anamīvā ayakṣmā asmabhyaṃ santu pṛthivi prasūtāḥ | dīrghaṃ na āyuḥ pratibudhyamānā vayaṃ tubhyaṃ balihṛtaḥ syāma ||
translation: Let the earth's long-productive harvests, free from disease, be present for us. May we, becoming tribute-payers to you, awaken to a long life.

sloka: indro yātūnāmabhavatparāśaro havirmathīnāmabhyā vivāsatām abhīdu śakraḥ paraśuryathā vanaṃ pātreva bhindantsata eti rakṣasaḥ
translation: Indra, foremost of the wielders of weapons, and Parashara, chief of those who offer sacrifices, indeed shone in their respective roles. Just as a sharp weapon can split open a container, so did the rakshasas (here possibly used to mean powerful beings) break open the forest with him (Indra or Parashara?) as their instrument/tool.

sloka: nahi nu yādadhīmasīndraṃ ko vīryā paraḥ tasminnṛmṇamuta kratuṃ devā ojāṃsi saṃ dadhurarcannanu svarājyam
translation: Indeed, who among men is superior in vigor to Yadahimsi-Indra? In that regard, the gods bestowed strength and chose to honor him with the sovereign power of performing the sacrificial rite.

sloka: indrasyāṅagirasāṃ ceṣṭau vidat saramā tanayāya dhāsim bṛhaspatirbhinadadriṃ vidad gāḥ samusriyābhirvāvaśanta naraḥ evaṃ purā svānapi sodarān sa garbhasthitānujjarituṃ bhayārtaḥ| bibheda vajreṇa tataḥ sa gotrabhit khyāto
translation: In the past, Indra struck

sloka: devā ūcurindro vai devānāmojiṣṭho baliṣṭhaḥ sahiṣṭhaḥ sattamaḥ pārayiṣṇutamastaṃ
translation: The gods said, "Indra is indeed the most choiceable, the strongest, and the most auspicious among the gods. Fulfill this task."

sloka: pūrvaṃ kṛtayuge tāta parvatāḥ pakṣiṇo'bhavan te hi jagmurdiśaḥ sarvā garuḍānilaveginaḥ
translation: In the past, during the first age, father, mountains became birds that flew swiftly in all directions; they indeed moved away.

sloka: tatasteṣu prayāteṣu devasaṃghaḥ saharṣibhiḥ bhūtāni ca bhayaṃ jagmusteṣāṃ patanaśaṅkayā
translation: Then, at the end of their (the gods and ṛṣis) journeys, a feeling of fear arose in the beings as they worried about the fall of those.

sloka: tataḥ kruddhaḥ sahasrākṣaḥ parvatānāṃ śatakratuḥ pakṣān ciccheda vajreṇa tatra tatra sahasraśaḥ
translation: Then, having become angry, Indra of a thousand eyes, wielder of thunder, split the wings of the mountains into pieces with his thunderbolt, here and there, in thousands.

sloka: devapitṛkāryābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam |
translation: The duties to the gods and ancestors should not be neglected.

sloka: nṛyajño'tithipūjanam
translation: The worship of the guest is a sacrifice for men.

sloka: mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava |
translation: Be the divine mother, be the divine father, cause to become the divine teacher, cause to become the divine guest.

sloka: rājartviksnātakagurūnpriyaśvaśuramātulān | arhayenmadhuparkeṇa parisaṃvatsarātpunaḥ | | | | saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | | | |
translation: The priest, recently initiated and dear to the king, should honor the teachers, fathers-in-law, and maternal uncles with a feast of honey. Offering a seat and water, he should respectfully give (them) food and other things according to his ability and following proper procedure, as the time arrives for hosting this event for the guest.

sloka: sattvaṃ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisaṃbhavāḥ | nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinamavyayam ||
translation: The three qualities (guṇāḥ) of nature, sattva, rajas, and tamas, which arise from prakṛti, bind the imperishable self in the body, O mighty-armed one.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: In the realm of happiness, the pure consciousness (sattva) prevails, O Bhārata, while desire (rajaḥ) becomes active in the field of actions. When obscured by ignorance (tamaḥ), knowledge is overcome by delusion; indeed, such is the case.

sloka: rajastamaścābhibhūya sattvaṃ bhavati bhārata | rajaḥ sattvaṃ tamaścaiva tamaḥ sattvaṃ rajastathā ||
translation: By overcoming rajas and tamas, O Bharata, the sattva becomes. Likewise, sattva, rajas, and tamas each become the others.

sloka: māṃ ca yo'vyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate | sa guṇānsamatītyaitānbrahmabhūyāya kalpate || brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāhamamṛtasyāvyayasya ca | śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaikāntikasya ca ||
translation: The one who devoutly serves me, without deviation, is eligible for gaining the qualities of Brahman and attaining union with the immortal and inexhaustible Brahman, the foundation of eternal dharma and ultimate bliss.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣeyaḥ yonāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavatyamataṃ matamavijñāātaṃ vijñātamiti kathaṃ nu bhagavaḥ sa ādeśo bhavatīti
translation: How can that be called a command, which has not been heard (unheard of), yet is heard (known to some), and which is neither accepted nor rejected by you?

sloka: hovācānanuśiṣya vāva kila mā bhagavānabravīdanutvā'śiṣamiti
translation: "The renowned one then said to his disciple, 'Let us also both instruct.'"

sloka: pañca mā rājanyabandhuḥ praśrnāprākṣītteṣāṃ naikaṃ ca nāśakaṃ vivaktumiti
translation: Don't five of you, bound by royal lineage, have the resolve to individually speak out against even a single destructive act.

sloka: sa hovāca yathā mā tvaṃ tadaitānavado yathā'hameṣāṃ naikaṃ ca na veda yadyahamimānavediṣyaṃ kathaṃ te nāvakṣyāmiti
translation: He asked, "Why wouldn't you explain these to me just as I don't know even one thing among them? How could I not make you understand if I intend to?"

sloka: mānuṣasya bhagavangautama vittasya varaṃ vṛṇīthā iti
translation: You, O Bhagavan Gautama, should choose the most excellent (vara) among human wealth.

sloka: sa hovāca tavaiva rājanmānuṣaṃ vittaṃ yāmeva kumārasyānte vācamabhāṣathāstāmeva me brūhiti sa ha kṛcchrī babhūva
translation: The king asked: "You surely have acquired human wealth, which the young prince spoke of at the end. You say (addressing to the king in the imperfect-indicative class 1 middle second-person singular) you have experienced hardship."

sloka: sūryaḥ dyusthānaḥ | vāyuḥ vā indraḥ vā antarikṣasthānaḥ | agniḥ pṛthivīsthānaḥ |
translation: The sun is in its (own) place in the sky, or perhaps it is wind, or maybe Indra in his position in the mid-region; or it could be fire on its earthly base.

sloka: aṅgayanti agyraṃ janma prāpayanti itivyutpattyā aṅgati ūrddhvaṃ gacchati iti agi gatau ||
translation: They cause to emerge what is not born, setting in motion the birth process; they make it ascend, as they themselves have already moved on.

sloka: sa vā eṣo'gre devatānāmajāyatā tasmādagrirnāmāgrirha vai nāmaitadyadagnirityāhuḥ sa u jātaḥ pūrvaḥ prayāya tadvaivāsya dvitīyamagritvaṃ pūrvaṃhi yantamāhuragra etīti ||
translation: Indeed, this one, being firstborn, was the origin of the names of the gods. Therefore, the east is called agri, and the home (fireplace) is named after agni. He was born before, and now he proceeds as the second flame in the form of fire.

sloka: prajāpatirha vā idamagra eka evāsa | sa aikṣata kathaṃ nu prajāyeyeti so'śrāmyatsa tapo'tapyata so'gnimeva mukhājjanayāṃcakre tadyadenaṃ mukhādajanayata tasmādannādo'gniḥ
translation: In the beginning, Lord Prajapati alone existed. He contemplated, "How should I procreate?" Having decided to do so through austerity, he performed severe penances. Like a fire that is kindled and then generates heat and produces flames, similarly, having kindled his own body through austerity, he created offspring from it. Therefore, the designation "Agni" (fire) for that which is eaten (annada) comes from there.

sloka: agnimūrdhā cakṣuṣī candrasūryau diśa: śrotre vāgvivṛtāśca vedā: vāyu: prāṇo hṛdayaṃ viśvamasya padbhayāṃ pṛthivī hyeṣa sarvabhūtāntarātmā sthālīsthānaṃ gato'śvatthaṃ śamīgarbhaṃ vilakṣya saḥ | tena dve araṇī kṛtvā urvaśīlokakāmyayā || ||
translation: The one with the crown like Agni, endowed with sight as Candra and Surya, comprehending all directions, associated with speech and the Vedas, pervading air as life force, enlivening the heart of the universe, identified as Sarvabhutantatma, established in the base as a stable Ashvattha tree, with its seed as Sami, recognized thus, he, having performed the Urvasiloka's desire, created two Araṇīs.

sloka: urvaśīṃ mantrato dhyāyan adharāraṇimuttarām | ātmānaṃ ubhayormadhye yattat prajananaṃ prabhuḥ || ||
translation: Meditating on Urvasi by means of mantras, the lord in the middle of both realms reflects upon his own self and the source of procreation.

sloka: tasya nirmanthanāt jāto jātavedā vibhāvasuḥ | trayyā sa vidyayā rājñā putratve kalpitastrivṛt || ||
translation: Born from its churning, Jātavedas Vibhāvasu has emerged, made manifest through the threefold knowledge and designated for paternity.

sloka: jātavedāḥ kasmāt | jātavit yaḥ vā jātaprajñānaḥ | jātāni veda | tasya eṣā bhavati | jāte jāte vidyate iti vā | jātadhanaḥ |
translation: Born one, Agni, wherefrom? The one who is born and knows or the one who is self-aware and born, who knows the births of all, to him this (knowledge) becomes. At his birth, (some say) it exists. Rich in possessions, he is.

sloka: tantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthitiḥ siddhāntaḥ || {siddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The established conclusion regarding the acceptance of the subject matter of a treatise.

sloka: dvividho hi vedokto dharmaḥ pravṛttilakṣaṇo nivṛttilakṣaṇaśca jagataḥ stithikāraṇam prāṇināṃ sākṣādabhyudayaniḥśreyasaheturya
translation: The dharma, as described in the Vedas, has two aspects: it promotes progress (pravrttilakṣaṇaḥ) and inhibits regress (nivrttilakṣaṇaḥ) in living beings, serving as a direct means for their upliftment and ultimate well-being.

sloka: hiṃsraṃ dravyamayaṃ kāmyamagnihotrādyaśāntidam darśaśca pūrṇamāsaśca cāturmāsyaṃ paśuḥ sutaḥ etadiṣṭaṃ pravṛttākhyaṃ hutaṃ prahutameva ca pūrtaṃ surālayārāma kūpā jīvyādilakṣaṇam
translation: The object is something destructive, made of material resources, desired for rituals such as the agnihotra and intended to bring about peace. The darsha and purnamasa rituals, along with a caturmasya animal sacrifice that has been offered and completely fulfilled, are characterized by a place of enjoyment, a shelter, a pit, and provisions for life as indicators of worldly existence.

sloka: naṣṭo mohaḥ smṛtirlabdhā tvatprasādānmayācyuta | sthito'smi gatasandehaḥ kariṣye vacanaṃ tava || ||
translation: My delusion has been destroyed, O Acyuta, through your grace; I have gained my memory back and stand firm with no doubts. I will carry out your command.

sloka: saṃnyāsaḥ karmayogaśca niḥśreyasakarāvubhau | tayostu karmasaṃnyāsātkarmayogo viśiṣyate || ||
translation: Renunciation and karma-yoga, both lead to liberation. However, between the two, karma-yoga, characterized by renunciation of fruitive actions, is superior.

sloka: tapasvibhyo'dhiko yogī jñānibhyo'pi mato'dhikaḥ | karmibhyaścādhiko yogī tasmādyogī bhavārjuna || ||
translation: A yogi is considered superior to ascetics, more knowledgeable than the wise, and better in actions than the materialists. Therefore, become a yogi, O Arjuna.

sloka: puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyastvananyayā | yasyāntaḥsthāni bhūtāni yena sarvamidaṃ tatam || ||
translation: The supreme being, O Partha, is attainable through devotion and only in this way. This being is the one within whom all beings reside and who pervades all that exists.

sloka: udārāḥ sarva evaite jñānī tvātmaiva me matam | āsthitaḥ sa hi yuktātmā māmevānuttamāṃ gatim || ||
translation: All of these are generous, in my view the knowing one is none but his own self. Established in oneself, he indeed partakes in the best fate, for me (is) that supreme destination.

sloka: tasmādasaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma samācara | asakto hyācarankarma paramāpnoti pūruṣaḥ || ||
translation: Therefore, always dedicatedly perform your duty; an unattached person is the one who obtains the supreme.

sloka: brahmaṇyādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ | lipyate na sa pāpena padmapatramivāmbhasā || ||
translation: The one who, having placed actions in Brahman, discards attachment and acts thus, is not tainted by sin, just like a lotus leaf remains unsullied by water.

sloka: sarvopaniṣado gāvo dogdhā gopālanandanaḥ | pārtho vatsaḥ sudhīrbhoktā dugdhaṃ gītāmṛtaṃ mahat ||
translation: "All the Upanishads are like cows, and Lord Krishna, the son of Gopala, is the calves that milk them. The wise Sudheer is the drinker of this milk, which is the nectar of the Bhagavad Gita's teachings."

sloka: kasminnu bhagavo vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavatīti || ||
translation: Bhagavan, only when one knows which one, do all these become known to him.

sloka: mamaivāṃśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ| manaḥṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛtisthāni karṣati||||
translation: I, indeed, am a portion of the eternal soul present in this world, and so are the six senses and the mind, which are drawn toward their respective objects according to their nature.

sloka: virāṭsutāḥ somasadaḥ sādhyānāṃ pitaraḥ smṛtāḥ | agniṣvāttāśca devānāṃ mārīcā lokaviśrutāḥ daityadānavayakṣāṇāṃ gandharvoragarakṣasām | suparṇakinnarāṇāṃ ca smṛtā barhiṣado'trijāḥ
translation: The offspring of Virat are remembered as the fathers of the Sadas offered to Soma, the worshipped ones in the sacrifices of the Sadhyas. Similarly, they are recognized as the resplendent beings among the gods, and as the terrifying ones among the Daityas, Danavas, Yakshas, Gandharvas, Nagas, and Rakshasas. Among the Parans and Kinnaras, they are known as the offspring of Barhisad.

sloka: somapā nāma viprāṇāṃ kṣatriyāṇāṃ havirbhujaḥ | vaiśyānāṃ ājyapā nāma śūdrāṇāṃ tu sukālinaḥ somapāstu kaveḥ putrā haviṣmanto'ṅgiraḥsutāḥ | pulastyasyājyapāḥ putrā vasiṣṭhasya sukālinaḥ
translation: The Soma drink is named among the Brahmins, and the Kshatriyas call it Havyabhuja. Among the Vaishyas, it is known as Ajya, while among the Shudras, it is called Sukala. The sons of Angirasa, who are skilled in offerings, are named Soma among the wise; they are the offspring of Pulastya and Vasiṣṭha.

sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are Vasanta (spring), Grishma (summer), and Varsha (monsoon); these are the ritus (seasons), while Sharat (autumn), Hemant (pre-winter), and Shishir (winter) are the pitrs (ancestors).

sloka: kāma eṣa krodha eṣa rajoguṇasamudbhavaḥ | mahāśano mahāpāpmā viddhyenamiha vairiṇam ||
translation: This desire and anger, born of the mode of passion, are indeed great purveyors of evil. Consider them here your enemies.

sloka: kāmamāśritya duṣpūraṃ dambhamānamadānvitāḥ | mohādgṛhītvāsadgrāhānpravartante'śucivratāḥ ||
translation: Relying on desire, arrogant and intoxicated by pride, they adopt impure resolutions through delusion, and thus engage in improper actions.

sloka: ahan vṛtraṃ vṛtrataraṃ vyaṃsamindro vajreṇa mahatā vadhena | skandhāṃsīva kuliśenā vivṛkṇā'hi: śayata upapṛk pṛthivyāḥ ||
translation: Indra, like a bolt of lightning, struck down the mightier Vrtra with his great weapon. Like tree trunks uprooted by a whirlwind, did the limbs of Vrtra lie scattered on the ground.

sloka: tava cyautnāni vajrahasta tāni nava yatpuro navatiṃ ca sadyaḥ niveśane śatatamāviveṣīrahañca vartraṃ namucimutāhan
translation: Your lightninglike fists, O hurler of the thunderbolt, those new ones and nine others along with them, as well as a new ninety, immediately investigate and destroy that danger from the two settlements, and also kill the enemy named Namuci.

sloka: śateṣu jāyate śūraḥ sahasreṣu ca paṇḍitaḥ | vaktā śatasahasreṣu dātā bhavati vā na vā ||
translation: In twenties, a hero is born, among thousands a scholar; in hundreds, becomes a speaker, or perhaps not, and a giver too.

sloka: kuṭumbabharaṇāddravyaṃ yatkiṃcidatiricyate | taddeyaṃ upahṛtyānyaddadaddoṣaṃ avāpnuyāt | | | |
translation: Whatever possession, beyond a little, one reserves for their family, they will acquire blame if they use it; they should distribute it and avoid acquiring fault.

sloka: indriyaprītyarthasya tu bhikṣaṇamanimittam | na tadādriyeta ::: yoktā ca dharmayukteṣu dravyaparigraheṣu ca ::: pratipādayitā ca tīrthe :::
translation: The purpose of begging for sustenance is to please the senses, but one should not become attached to it. Moreover, one should follow religious duties while acquiring material possessions and also establish (them) in holy places.

sloka: yantā cātīrthe yato na bhayaṃ syāt ::: saṃgrahītā ca manuṣyān :::
translation: Where one can travel to holy sites without fear and can persuade people.

sloka: deśataḥ kālataḥ śaucataḥ samyak pratigrahītṛta iti dānāni pratipādayati :::
translation: He lays down that gifts should be given after considering the proper time , place , and purity , and when one is capable of receiving them appropriately.

sloka: mekhalādhāraṇabhaikṣacaryadaṇḍasamidādhānopasparśanaprātarabhivādā nityam
translation: Performing the daily acts of respectfully greeting others in the morning, handling the mendicant's staff, and accepting alms after placing the firestick and water pot, along with wearing the lower garment. (Here, nityam is an adverb modifying the verbal actions and is not part of the list.)

sloka: brahma jñānaṃ tapo vā ācarati arjayatyavaśyam| upanayanānantaraṃ niyamaṃ kṛtvā guroḥ sannidhausthitvā sāṅgavedādhyayanaṃ karoti yaḥ | sa dbividhaḥ upakurvvāṇaḥ naiṣṭhikaśca | prathamāśramī |
translation: One who, being obligated, performs the study of the Vedas and other traditional duties such as the initiation ceremony (upanayana) immediately after, established in the presence of the guru, is of two types: one who acts dutifully and the other who is firmly committed to this first stage of life.

sloka: codito guruṇā nityaṃ apracodita eva vā | kuryādadhyayane yatnaṃ ācāryasya hiteṣu ca | | | |
translation: Let the disciple, taught or untaught, always make an effort in studying and serving the teacher.

sloka: uṣitvaivaṃ gurukule dvijo'dhītyāvabudhya ca | trayīṃ sāṅgopaniṣadaṃ yāvadarthaṃ yathābalam || ||
translation: Having resided in the spiritual preceptor's home, a dvija (twice-born) should recognize and understand the import of the triple science along with the Upanishads, to the best of his ability.

sloka: vedayajñairahīnānāṃ praśastānāṃ svakarmasu | brahmacāryāharedbhaikṣaṃ gṛhebhyaḥ prayato'nvaham | | | | guroḥ kule na bhikṣeta na jñātikulabandhuṣu | alābhe tvanyagehānāṃ pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ vivarjayet | | | | sarvaṃ vāpi caredgrāmaṃ pūrvoktānāṃ asaṃbhave | niyamya prayato vācaṃ abhiśastāṃstu varjayet | | | |
translation: To the praiseworthy one, engaged in his own duties, who is not present at the sacrificial rites, let the brahmachari beg for alms bhikshA eta from the teacher's home, not from relatives. If not available there, he should first avoid other houses. He may live in the village, following the previously mentioned rules, after making sure that everything is in order. He should carefully avoid harsh speech while regulating his own words.

sloka: brahmacārī vratī nityaṃ nityaṃ dīkṣāparo vaśī | gurucchāyānugo nityamadhīyānaḥ suyantritaḥ | avicālyavratopetaṃ kṛtyaṃ kurvanvasetsadā ||
translation: The constantly self-restrained and vowed adherent of the brahmacarya lifestyle, who has steadfastly taken up the initiation ritual, is always under the guidance of the guru's shadow and is well-trained. He should always perform the duties required by this unfailing and firmly established disciplined conduct.

sloka: suśīlo mitabhugdakṣaḥ śraddadhāno jitendriyaḥ | yāvadarthaṃ vyavaharetstrīṣu strīnirjiteṣu ca || ||
translation: Remaining virtuous, having tasted sweetness, skilled, and with controlled senses, he acts on his purpose in women and in those who have been conquered.

sloka: vasanneko japannekaḥ sarvānvedānyudhiṣṭhira | ekasminneva cācārye śuśrūṣurmalapaṅkavān ||
translation: Yudhishthira, who is to be served, is one who diligently studies all the Vedas in a single teacher, being unattached to the impurities of worldly existence.

sloka: śayyāsane'dhyācarite śreyasā na samāviśet | śayyāsanasthaścaivainaṃ pratyutthāyābhivādayet | | | | ūrdhvaṃ prāṇā hyutkrāmanti yūnaḥ sthavira āyati | pratyutthānābhivādābhyāṃ punastānpratipadyate | | | |
translation: In the place of resting, one should not settle in what is most beneficial; but rather, having established oneself there, should greet him upon rising. For, when young or old rise and pay their respects, vitality returns to them.

sloka: śreyaḥsu guruvadvṛttiṃ nityaṃ eva samācaret | guruputreṣu cāryeṣu guroścaiva svabandhuṣu | | | | bālaḥ samānajanmā vā śiṣyo vā yajñakarmaṇi | adhyāpayangurusuto guruvanmānaṃ arhati | | | | yathā khanankhanitreṇa naro vāryadhigacchati | tathā gurugatāṃ vidyāṃ śuśrūṣuradhigacchati | | | |
translation: Su (you), always properly follow the guru's conduct, which leads to welfare. Treat your guru's children and students as well as your own relatives. Whether a child or a student, one should assist the guru in performing rituals. One who causes the guru's son to learn deserves respect. Just like a man becomes respected through his actions, similarly, one becomes worthy of respect by serving the guru's knowledge.

sloka: varjayenmadhu māṃsaṃ ca gandhaṃ mālyaṃ rasānstriyaḥ | śuktāni yāni sarvāṇi prāṇināṃ caiva hiṃsanam | | | | abhyaṅgaṃ añjanaṃ cākṣṇorupānacchatradhāraṇam | kāmaṃ krodhaṃ ca lobhaṃ ca nartanaṃ gītavādanam | | | | dyūtaṃ ca janavādaṃ ca parivādaṃ tathānṛtam | strīṇāṃ ca prekṣaṇālambhaṃ upaghātaṃ parasya ca | | | |
translation: He should avoid in this context, causing harm to living beings , consuming alcohol , meat , fragrances , garlands , and other such things . He should also avoid using sharp objects , inflicting harm on others , engaging in gambling , arguments , gossip , dishonesty , and taking pleasure in looking at women . He should not act out of anger , greed , or excitement , and he should avoid hurting others intentionally.

sloka: prativedaṃ brahmacaryaṃ dvādaśābdāni pañca vā | grahaṇāntikaṃ ityeke keśāntaścaiva ṣoḍaśe | | | |
translation: Is it [this] brahmacarya of twelve or five days, they ask, as well as the point of hair-cutting that is designated "grahaṇāntika" and occurs on the sixteenth?

sloka: vedasvīkaraṇaṃ kṛtvā srāyādvai dattadakṣiṇaḥ | naiṣṭhiko brahmacārī vā dehāntaṃ nivasedgurau ||
translation: Having accomplished the exegesis of the Vedas, and having made a gift of the Dakshina, should a brahmachari, who is devoted to the path of truth, choose to renounce his body under the guidance of the guru.

sloka: yadi tvātyantikaṃ vāsaṃ rocayeta guroḥ kule | yuktaḥ paricaredenaṃ ā śarīravimokṣaṇāt | | | | ācārye tu khalu prete guruputre guṇānvite | gurudāre sapiṇḍe vā guruvadvṛttiṃ ācaret | | | | eteṣvavidyamāneṣu sthānāsanavihāravān | prayuñjāno'gniśuśrūṣāṃ sādhayeddehaṃ ātmanaḥ | | | |
translation: If you desire to serve fully in the guru's home, being prepared, perform this service for liberation of the body. When the guru has passed on, and his son is endowed with virtues, then carry out the guru's way of life in relation to the teacher's wife, son, or relative. If these positions are absent, one who seeks enlightenment should attend to fire rituals while engaged in activities related to place, seat, and behavior.

sloka: evaṃ carati yo vipro brahmacaryaṃ aviplutaḥ | sa gacchatyuttamasthānaṃ na ceha jāyate punaḥ | | | |
translation: The brahmachari (celibate student) who practices according to the rule, he attains the highest place and will not be reborn.

sloka: anena vidhinā dehaṃ sādayanvijitendriyaḥ | brahmalokaṃ avāpnoti na cehājāyate punaḥ | | | |
translation: By following this rule, a self-controlled individual who has mastered the senses can attain the abode of Brahma after abandoning the body and is not reborn again.

sloka: āvasathyādhānaṃ dārakāle dāyādyakāla ekeṣām ||
translation: During the time of a child's upbringing, some consider the arranging of a dwelling (for the teacher) to be their duty.

sloka: kaccid agniṣu te yukto vidhijno matimān ṛjuḥ hutam ca hoṣyamāṇam ca kāle vedayate sadā samidhaḥpāvanāḥ pūjyāḥ carmayuktāḥ parātparāḥ yuṣmān harāmi homārthaṃ asmān rakṣata sarvadā ||
translation: Is there someone among you who is properly joined in sacrifices with the Agni, knowledgeable, wise, and performing correct rituals, who always knows what should be done at the right time? The sacred samidha firewood is to be honored and used in the rites, as well as the pure skin. Protect us both, O Uma's consort, in every way during this homa offering.

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda atharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśidaivo nidhirvākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyā brahmavidyā bhūtavidyā kṣatravidyā nakṣatravidyā sarpadevajñavidyā nāmaivaitannāmopāssveti
translation: The names indeed are Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda, and Atharvan, the fourth; Itihasa-Purana is the fifth among the Vedas. Pitrya and Rashi are, respectively, the treasure of knowledge related to divine and human realms. What is that study, consisting of a single knowledge system, addressing gods, Brahman, elements, Kshatra, Nakshatras, serpents, and their related disciplines? You (two) studied them, know them, and now protect and preserve them.

sloka: mano vāva vāco bhūyo yathā vai dve vā''malake mano hyātmā mano loko mano hi brahma mana upāssveti
translation: "Or did you meditate on the mind, speech, and senses as superior, just as on two lotus leaves? Indeed, the self is the mind, the world is the mind; the mind is also Brahman. Meditate on the mind."

sloka: dhyānaṃ vāva cittādbhūyo dhyāyatīva pṛthavī dhyāyatīvāntarikṣaṃ dhyāyatīva dyaurdhyāyatīva''po dhyāyantīva parvatā dhyāyantīva devamanuṣyāstasmādya iha manuṣyāṇāṃ mahattāṃ prapnuvanti dhyānāpādā~ śā ivaiva te dhyānamupāssveti
translation: "Meditating, indeed, on the Self within, one should meditate as if on earth, as if on the atmosphere, as if on the sky, as if on the mountains, as if on the gods and humans. Therefore, it is through meditation that people of great stature here and now attain those initial steps of meditation."

sloka: balaṃ vāva vijñānādbhūyo'pi ha śataṃ vijñānavatāseko balavānākampayate sa yadā balī bhavatyathotthātā bhavatyuttiṣṭhan paricaritā bhavati paricarannupasatta bhavatyupasīdandraṣṭā bhavati śrotā bhavati mantā bhavati bodhdā bhavati balamupāssveti
translation: Indeed, knowledge is superior even by a hundred times over to strength. The one who has pursued knowledge becomes stronger when he truly becomes powerful and rises up, begins to act in service, steadily engages in attending to and reflecting upon it, becomes a seer, hearer, ponderer, and conscious being. One should attend to strength in this way.

sloka: annaṃ vāva balādbhūyastasmādyadyapi daśarātrārnāśrnīyādyadyu ha jīvedathavā'draṣṭā'śrotā'mantā'bodhdā'kartā'vijñātā bhavatyathānnasyā''yai draṣṭā bhavati śrotā bhavati mantā bhavati bodhdā bhavati kartā bhavati vijñātā bhavatyannamupāssveti
translation: "Did you all, with even greater strength, partake of it in the past? Therefore, even now, if one is living or observing, understanding, cognizing, or knowing it, they become the seer, hearer, ponderer, knower, and experiencer of that annam (food). So, you should attend to annam."

sloka: āpo vāvānnādbhūyasyastasmādyadā suvṛṣṭirna bhavati vyādhīyante prāṇā annaṃ kanīyo bhaviṣyatītyatha yadā suvṛṣṭirbhavatyānandinaḥ prāṇā bhavantyannaṃ bahu bhaviṣyatītyāpa evemā mūrtā yeyaṃ pṛthavī yadantarikṣaṃ mūrtā apa upāssveti
translation: When rain doesn't occur, all beings of the living world suffer, and food becomes scarce. But when rain does come, they flourish. Similarly, this earth and the atmosphere also take form when nourished. Just as you (singular imperative) should observe and contemplate upon them.

sloka: tejo vāvādbhyo bhūyastadvā etadvāyumāgṛhnā''kāśamabhitapati tadā''hurniśocati nitapati varṣiṣyati vā iti teja eva tatpūrvaṃ darśayitvā'thāpaḥ sṛjate tadetadūrdhvābhiśca tiraścībhiśca vidyudbhirāhrādāścaranti teja upāssveti
translation: From the radiant ones, it (the light) has increased even more. Then, whether it illuminates widely or narrowly, whether it gleams or sets, whether it will rain or not, it is indeed that radiance which first manifests itself; afterward, it causes activity in entities such as water. One should meditate on that radiance which is scattered by upward and downward lightning and pervades the rivers.

sloka: ākāśo vāva tejaso bhūyānākāśe vai sūryā candramasāvubhau vidyunnakṣatrāṇyagnirākāśenā''hvayatyākāśena pratiśrṛṇotyākāśe ramata ākāśe na ramata ākāśe jāyata ākāśamabhijāyata ākāśamupāssveti
translation: Indeed, you were spread out as light in the sky, and in the sky you bring together the sun and the moon. In the sky you move about, and from the sky your sound is heard. You delight in the sky, but do not delight on the sky; you are born from the sky, you are produced in the sky, and you should meditate upon the sky.

sloka: smaro vāvā''kāśādbhūyastasmādyadyapi bahava āsīranna smaranto naiva te kaṃcana śṛṇuyurnamanvīranna vijānīranyadā vāva te smareyuratha śṛṇuyuratha manvīrannatha vijānīransmareṇa vai putrānvijānāti smareṇa paśūnsmaramupāssveti
translation: The one who remembers is indeed rare, even now many have taken to forgetting. Those being remembered by them do not hear anything, nor do they comprehend anything. At some point, if they were to remember, then perhaps they would hear and comprehend. Indeed, the one who knows his sons through remembering, he takes care of his cattle by remembering.

sloka: āśā vāva smarādbhūyasyāśeddho vai smaro mantrānadhīte karmaṇi kurute putrā~śca paśū~ścecchata imaṃ ca lokamamuṃ cecchata āśāmupāssveti
translation: The desire indeed is constantly remembering the imperishable , and the one who remembers is surely accomplished in reciting the mantras . He performs actions for both his sons and animals . He takes care of this world as well as the other .

sloka: prāṇo vā āśāyā bhūyānyathā vā arā nābhau samarpitā evamasminprāṇe sarva~samarpitaṃ prāṇaḥ prāṇena yāti prāṇaḥ prāṇaṃ dadāti prāṇāya dadāti prāṇo ha pitā prāṇo mātā prāṇo bhrātā prāṇaḥ svasā prāṇa ācāryaḥ prāṇo brahmaṇaḥ
translation: The life force (prāṇaḥ) is offered to the navel (nabhau) here; all is offered in this life force. Through the life force, one goes; the life force gives to the life force, gives to the life force. The life force is the father, the life force is the mother, the life force is the brother, the life force is the sister, the life force is the teacher, the life force of the Brahman.

sloka: yo vai bhūmā tatsukhaṃ nālpe sukhamasti bhūmaiva sukhaṃ bhūmā tveva vijijñāsitavya iti bhūmānaṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: Indeed, the one who is supreme finds true happiness, not in fleeting pleasures . The truly happy one is indeed the one who has to be sought after . So, O Lord , seek to understand the supreme !

sloka: yatra nānyatpaśyati nānyacchṛṇoti nānyadvijānāti sa bhūmā'tha yatrānyatpaśyatyanyacchṛṇotyanyadvijānāti tadalpaṃ yo vai bhūmā tadamṛtamatha yadalpaṃ tanmartya~sa bhagavaḥ kasminpratiṣṭhita iti sve mahimni yadi vā na mahimnīti
translation: Where one sees nothing else, hears nothing else, and knows nothing else, that is the great; but what is small is mortal. As for the deity who is established in his own majesty or not in it, that is the immortal or the mortal.

sloka: aparābādhamakleśaṃ prayatnenārjītaṃ dhanam | svalpaṃ vā vipulaṃ vāpi deyamityabhidīyate ||
translation: Wealth, free from the taint of causing harm to others, is said to be acquired through earnest effort; whether it is small or great, it is to be given.

sloka: vyākhyā api tantrasya guṇaḥ| tābhirapi tantramalaṅikrayate | tāśca pañcadaśa prakārā |
translation: Explanation is also a quality of the treatise; it gets adorned with those very qualities. These are indeed fifteen in number.

sloka: indro dadhīco asthabhirvṛtrāṇyapratiṣkutaḥ jaghāna navatīrnava
translation: Indra and Dadhici, having become invulnerable to the host of demons, had destroyed ninety-nine.

sloka: ichannaśvasya yacchiraḥ parvateṣvapaśritam tada vidaccharyaṇāvati
translation: The tip of the Ichanna's hair, resting on those mountain peaks, is visible from the Śaryaṇāvat location.

sloka: maghavān yāta bhadraṃ vo dadhyāñcamṛṣisattamam vidyāvratatapaḥsāraṃ gātraṃ yācata mā ciram
translation: Maghavan, you who are noble, have arrived; seek the best physical form, which is the essence of austerity, knowledge, and vows, and is superior. Don't delay in seeking this excellent ṛṣi-sattama body, which is the result of your diligent practice and study.

sloka: sa vā adhigato dadhyaṅṅaśvibhyāṃ brahma niṣkalam yad vā aśvaśiro nāma yatoramaratāṃ vyadhāt
translation: Indeed, it has been attained by Dadhyanc and the two Ashvins that indivisible Brahman, namely the horse's head, which (Brahman) he (Dadhyanc) established for immortality.

sloka: dadhyaṅṅātharvaṇastvaṣṭre varmābhedyaṃ madātmakam viśvarūpāya yat prādāt tvaṣṭā yat tvamadhāstataḥ
translation: Ātharvaṇa, endowed with divine powers, who are you that Tvaṣṭā bestowed upon and made indivisible, all-encompassing, and the intoxicating essence of; you, rising from there, have become the second singular person?

sloka: yuṣmabhyaṃ yācato'śvibhyāṃ dharmajño'ṅgāni dāsyati tatastairāyudhaśreṣṭho viśvakarmavinirmitaḥ yena vṛtraśiro hartā mattejaupabṛṃhitaḥ
translation: To you two, the wise one will give the limbs when asked from their horses , the best creator of all actions , with which the head of Vṛtra was taken by him, through those weapons .

sloka: tasmin vinihate yūyaṃ tejo'strāyudhasampadaḥ bhūyaḥ prapsyatha bhadraṃ vo na hiṃsanti ca matpurān
translation: In that fallen one, you all will again acquire the endowment of martial prowess. May you fare well! Indeed, they do not harm the maternal abode.

sloka: etaddhyevākṣaraṃ brahma etaddhyevākṣaraṃ param | etaddhyevākṣaraṃ jñātvā yo yadicchati tasya tat || ||
translation: This syllable alone is the absolute Brahman; knowing this syllable, one gets what one desires.

sloka: etadvai satyakāma paraṃ cāparaṃ ca brahma yadoṅkāraḥ |
translation: Indeed, O Satyakama, this alone is the ultimate Brahman: the syllable Om. And also that which is beyond it.

sloka: dve vāva brahmaṇo rūpe mūrtaṃ caivāmūrtaṃ ca martyaṃ cāmṛtaṃ ca sthitaṃ ca yacca sacca tyacca || ||
translation: Are you referring to the two forms of Brahman, both manifested and unmanifested, mortal and immortal, stable and ever-present?

sloka: anyacchreyo'nyadutaiva preyaste ubhe nānārthe puruṣa~ sinītaḥ | tayoḥ śreya ādadānasya sādhu bhavati hīyate'rthādya u preyo vṛṇīte || ||
translation: Preferring one over the other, both of different purposes, a person should adopt the superior one; by doing so, they neither lose the inferior nor lack merit, and they choose what is most preferred.

sloka: śreyaśca preyaśca manuṣyametaḥ tau samparītya vivinakti dhīraḥ | śreyo hi dhīro'bhi preyaso vṛṇīte preyo mando yogakṣemādvṛṇīte || ||
translation: The wise one distinguishes between what is advantageous and pleasurable for man, for the discerning chooses advantageous over the pleasing, while the dull-witted opts for immediate pleasure, neglecting welfare and safety.

sloka: sa tvaṃ priyānpriyarūpāṃśca kāmān abhidhyāyannaciketo'tyasrākṣīḥ | naitā~ sṛṅkāṃ vittamayīmavāpto yasyāṃ majjanti bahavo manuṣyāḥ || ||
translation: You, who are fond of and resemble dear ones, while pursuing such desires, remain ever vigilant. For, many people plunge into that famed, wealth-yielding abyss (srngkaam).

sloka: dūramete viparīte viṣūcī avidyā yā ca vidyeti jñātā | vidyābhīpsinaṃ naciketasaṃ manye na tvā kāmā bahavo'lolupanta || ||
translation: I consider Naciketas to be a seeker of knowledge, not those many, overwhelmed by desires, who know or do not know of this duality and the dispelling of ignorance, far or near.

sloka: avidyāyāmantare vartamānāḥ svayaṃ dhīrāḥ paṇḍitaṃmanyamānāḥ | dandramyamāṇāḥ pariyanti mūḍhā andhenaiva nīyamānā yathāndhāḥ || ||
translation: Engrossed in ignorance, the self-proclaimed wise, behaving foolishly, are led astray by their own delusion, just like the blind by a blind person.

sloka: na sāmparāyaḥ pratibhāti bālaṃ pramādyantaṃ vittamohena mūḍham | ayaṃ loko nāsti para iti mānī punaḥ punarvaśamāpadyate me || ||
translation: The true reality doesn't shine forth for a deluded person, immersed in the allure of wealth and behaving like a child. This world seems to be non-existent or something other than it truly is. Again and again, he becomes subject to this delusion.

sloka: ya ete pitṛdevānāmayane vedanirmite śāstreṇa cakṣuṣā veda janastho'pi na muhyati ādāvante janānāṃ sadbahirantaḥ parāvaram jñānaṃ jñeyaṃ vaco vācyaṃ tamo jyotistvayaṃ svayam
translation: The one who, with the scripture as their guide, can discern the true nature of the divine ancestors' course in this world, and remains unmoved by it even when first presented to them; such a one knows what must be known, says what must be said, and illuminates both inner and outer realms for others. This self-same one is the radiance of light, the source of knowledge, and the designation of all that can be designated.

sloka: agniḥ sūryo divā prāhṇaḥ śuklo rākottaraṃ svarāṭ viśvo'tha taijasaḥ prājñasturya ātmā samanvayāt devayānamidaṃ prāhurbhūtvā bhūtvānupūrvaśaḥ ātmayājyupaśāntātmā hyātmastho na nivartate
translation: "They declare this to be the divinely appointed path for the embodied soul: agni and surya, present during the day; the white and unobstructed one, independent in its own sphere; all-encompassing yet also taijasa (related to subtle body), prājña (conscious) and turya (transcendental); the ātman that pervades through samanvaya (connection); becoming various forms anupūrvashaḥ (in a new way, continuously). The one who is established in this ātma-yāja (worship of the self) and upaśānta (pacified), never retreats from it."

sloka: dravyasūkṣmavipākaśca dhūmo rātrirapakṣayaḥ ayanaṃ dakṣiṇaṃ somo darśa oṣadhivīrudhaḥ annaṃ reta iti kṣmeśa pitṛyānaṃ punarbhavaḥ ekaikaśyenānupūrvaṃ bhūtvā bhūtveha jāyate
translation: The subtle manifestation of substances, along with smoke, is the westward course of the sun, the autumn season, the lunar phase known as darśa, and the growth of herbs. Food and semen are called kṣmā-īśa. Pitṛyānaṃ punarbhavaḥ is one's rebirth as a result of each individual's actions, becoming and being reborn here.

sloka: tadya iha ramaṇīyacaraṇā abhyāśo ha yatte ramaṇīyāṃ yonimāpadyeranbrāhmaṇayoniṃ vā kṣatriyayoniṃ vā vaiśyayoniṃ vātha ya iha kapūyacaraṇā abhyāśo ha yatte kapūyāṃ yonimāpadyeran śvayoniṃ vā sūkarayoniṃ vā caṇḍālayoniṃ vā ||
translation: Are these two, who in this world are engaged in pleasant and foul actions, respectively, able to attain their respective wombs - the Brahmin's or the warrior's, or the Vaisya's; or even the Chandala's - through their actions?

sloka: tadantarapratipattau raṃhati sampariṣvaktaḥ praśnanirūpaṇābhyām
translation: In the pursuit of directly experiencing that (ultimate reality), he questions and investigates.

sloka: samānā cāsṛtyupakramādamṛtatvaṃ cānupoṣya
translation: She should similarly sustain eternal life from the very beginning of her growth.

sloka: śuklakṛṣṇe gatī hyete jagataḥ śāśvate mate | ekayā yātyanāvṛttimanyayāvartate punaḥ
translation: In the white and black (i.e., in day and night), these two paths of the transient world are eternally established; through the same one, beings proceed forward, and by another, they return.

sloka: agne devā~ ihā vaha sādayā yoniṣu triṣu | pari bhūṣa piba ṛtunā ||
translation: O Fire, bring here the gods and favor the three birthplaces. Get adorned and drink the libation with satisfaction.

sloka: dakṣiṇaṃ tveva prathamaṃ vijñāyate pitā vā eṣo'gnīnāṃ yaddakṣiṇaḥ putro gārhapatyaḥ pautra āhavanīyastasmādevaṃ paryukṣet
translation: Indeed, the southerly direction is recognized first. Surely, this is the father of the fires, namely the son who is called dakṣiṇa among them, the one of the gārhapatya and āhavanīya fires. Therefore, he should be duly honored.

sloka: ta eva hi trayo lokāsta eva traya āśramāḥ | ta eva hi trayo vedāsta evoktāstrayo'gnayaḥ | |
translation: These are indeed the three worlds, these are the three ashrams, and these are the three Vedas that have been described as the three fires.

sloka: pitā vai gārhapatyo'gnirmātāgnirdakṣiṇāḥ smṛtāḥ | gururāhavanīyastu sāgnitretā garīyasī ||
translation: Indeed, the father is remembered as the creator and the one who receives the oblations in the gārhapatya fire, while the teacher is considered superior as the nurturer of the āhavanīya fire.

sloka: triṣvapramādyanneteṣu trīllolokān vijayedgṛhī | dīpyamānaḥ svavapuṣāḥ devavadyivi modate ||
translation: Radiating with his own splendor, the one who has conquered the three worlds in the beginning of time rejoices, comparable to the devas.

sloka: nṛyajño'tithipūjanam
translation: The worship of the guest is a sacrifice for men.

sloka: kṛtvaitadbalikarmaivaṃ atithiṃ pūrvaṃ āśayet | bhikṣāṃ ca bhikṣave dadyādvidhivadbrahmacāriṇe | | | |
translation: Having done this task of hosting a guest, one should welcome him in advance. One should give alms to the mendicant in the prescribed manner.

sloka: vidyātapaḥsamṛddheṣu hutaṃ vipramukhāgniṣu | nistārayati durgācca mahataścaiva kilbiṣāt | | | |
translation: In the flourishing assembly of scholars and patrons of sacred knowledge, where offerings have been made in the priests' fires, do great men rescue each other from small and great sins, and from danger as well.

sloka: tapasah: tatmahinaajāyataekam
translation: The one who is born from self-less austerities became one (with the Absolute).

sloka: divyo hyamūrtaḥ puruṣaḥ sabāhyābhyantaro hyajaḥ apraṇo hyamanāḥ śubhro hyakṣarātparataḥ paraḥ
translation: The divine and ageless Purusha, untouched by either external or internal concerns, free from desire and without a physical form, shining and superior - originates from what is beyond the physical letters.

sloka: devānāṃ pūrvye yuge'sataḥ sadajāyata || devānāṃ yuge prathame'sataḥ sadajāyata | tadāśā anvajāyanta taduttānapadaspari ||
translation: In the preceding age, the ancestors of the gods were born from them; in the first age, the ancestors of the gods themselves were born. Then longings and desires arose around them.

sloka: ekam sat vipra bahudhā vadanti
translation: The sage recognizes the One Reality as manifold.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tato vai sadajāyata | tadātmāna~ svayamakuruta | tasmāttatsukṛtamucyata iti | yadvai tat sukṛtam | raso vai saḥ |
translation: Initially, this was non-existent. Then existence emerged from it. The very same [entity] spontaneously took the form of the Self. Therefore, it is known as having been created by itself. Indeed, that creation is pleasure itself.

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tadāhuḥ kiṃ tadasadāsīdityṛṣayo vāva te'gre'sadāsīt
translation: In the beginning, were there two of these non-existent entities? Then, you (plural) asked, "What was that non-existent before?" Indeed, it is the females of the seers who were always in existence.

sloka: so'yaṃ puruṣaḥ prajāpatirakāmayata bhūyāntsyāṃ prajāyeyeti so'śrāmyatsa tapo'tapyata sa śrāntastepāno brahmaiva prathamamasṛjata
translation: This man, Prajapati, had desired that there be more progeny. He practiced austerity and, having exhausted himself, first created Brahma in the form of the embodiment of that practice.

sloka: naiveha kiṃcanāgra āsīn mṛtyunaivedamāvṛtamāsīdaśanāyayā'śanāyā hi mṛtyus tanmano'kurutā''tmanvī syāmiti | so'rcannacarat tasyārcata āpo'jāyantārcate vai me kamabhūditi | ||
translation: In this world, who has ever remained separate from death, uncovered by it? Indeed, one should serve this deity, for waters are born from its worship. You become that which you worship; such is my wish.

sloka: nāsa̭dāsīnno sadā̭sīttadānīm nāsīdrajo no vyo̭mā paro yat| kimāva̭rīva: kuha kasya śarmannaṃbha: kimā̭sīdgaha̭naṃ gabhīram ||
translation: If you had not been here, then neither would the king have existed, nor our distant sky. What was like a fish in the water? Where was its protection, whose home was deep? What existed in it?

sloka: na mṛtyurā̭sīdamṛtaṃ na tarhi na rātryā ahna̭ āsītpraketaḥ| ānī̭davātaṃ svadhayā tadekaṃ tasmā̭ddhānyanna paraḥ kiñcanāsa̭||
translation: "Death cannot overcome that immortality, nor night and day. It has flowed alone from the very beginning; therefore there is nothing else beyond it."

sloka: tama̭ āsīttama̭sā gūl̤hamagrḙ'praketaṃ sa̭lilaṃ sarva̭mā idaṃ| tucchyenābhvapi̭hitaṃ yadāsīttapa̭sastanma̭hinā jā̭yataika̭ṃ|| ||
translation: From the beginning, what was unmanifest was dark and contained everything. It was subtle, invisible, and became manifest as a single entity through its own power.

sloka: kāmastadagre sama̭vartatādhi mana̭so reta̭: prathamaṃ yadāsī̭t| sato bandhumasa̭ti nira̭vindan hṛdi pratīṣyā̭ kavayo̭ manīṣā||
translation: When the mind first turns to desire, wise people recognize it dwelling in their hearts and prevent it from taking hold.

sloka: tiraścīno vita̭to raśmirḙṣāmadhaḥ svi̭dāsī dupari̭ svidāsī tat| retodhā ā̭sanmahimāna̭ āsantsvadhā āvastātpraya̭tiḥ parastā̭t||
translation: The fearful one, liberated from attachment, has become free from the web of prestige. He savors bliss above, below, and everywhere. His self has become unbound, steady; his end is elsewhere.

sloka: ko addhā vḙda ka iha pravo̭catkuta ājā̭tā kuta̭ iyaṃ visṛ̭ṣṭiḥ| arvāgdevā asya visarja̭ne॒nāthā॒ ko vḙda॒ yata̭ āba॒bhūva̭ ||
translation: Who in this world is currently a knower, who has been born and from where has this creation come about? Who will be the one to send off the gods after his departure, and who indeed was the one that became manifest first?

sloka: iyaṃ visṛ̭ṣṭiryata̭ ābabhūva yadi̭ vā dadhe yadi̭ vā na| yo asyādhya̭kṣaḥ parame vyo̭mantso aṅga vḙda yadi̭ vā na veda̭|| ||
translation: If this distinction became manifest or was bestowed by someone, or not, the one who knows its ruler in the highest firmament, or does not know - Anga Veda.

sloka: iṣṭaprāpti aniṣṭapariharyor alaukikam upāyam yo grantho vedayati sa vedaḥ
translation: The text that explains the exceptional means to attain desired ends and avoid undesired outcomes is indeed a scripture.

sloka: mantra brahmanyor vedanāmadheyam
translation: O mantra, designated as the essence of the Vedas and Brahman.

sloka: brahmamukhanirgatadharmmajñāpakaśāstram iti purāṇam
translation: The ancient treatise revealing the teachings that lead to the understanding of the path to Brahman.

sloka: tasmādṛca: sāma yajūṃṣi dīkṣā
translation: Therefore, the ṛcas, sāmans, and yajus form the initiation.

sloka: etasya vā mahato bhūtasya ni:śvasitametad yad ṛgvedo yajurveda: sāmavedo'tharvāṅgirasa
translation: Of this great being, is it not your command that the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, Atharvangirasa be recited?

sloka: dharmabrahmapratipādakamapauruṣeyavākyam iti vedāntaśāstram
translation: The treatise known as Vedanta-shastra, which establishes the meaning of "dharma" and "brahma" through impersonal statements, is what I am referring to.

sloka: na vedaśāstrādanyattu kiṃcicchāstraṃ hi vidyate | niḥsṛtaṃ sarvaśāstraṃ tu vedaśāstrāt sanātanam ||
translation: Nothing beyond the teachings of the Vedas exists as scripture. Indeed, all secular and spiritual knowledge originates from the Veda.

sloka: darśayataś caivaṃ pratyakṣānumāne |
translation: And they reveal in this way through direct perception.

sloka: mātāpitrorgurau mitre vinīte copakāriṇi | dīnānāthaviśiṣṭebhyo dattantu saphalaṃ bhavet ||
translation: Let the mother, father, teachers, and faithful friend bestow auspicious results upon the distressed and most excellent among the afflicted.

sloka: śrotriyāya daridrāya gṛhasthāyāgnihotriṇe| putradārābhibhūtāya tathā hyanupakāriṇe|| evaṃvidheṣu dātavyā na samṛddheṣu bhārata|
translation: To the teacher, the poor, the householder, the performer of agnihotra, and also to the one who has overcome sons and spouse, thus, O Bharata, those who are to be given away as alms should be given to such ones, not to the affluent.

sloka: dhūrte vandini mande ca kuvaidye kitave śaṭhe | cāṭucāraṇacaurabhyo dattaṃ bhavati niṣphalam ||
translation: To a deceitful person, offering even mandate respect becomes futile when done in the presence of a boastful, unintelligent, and cunning individual.

sloka: avyaktādvyaktayaḥ sarvāḥ prabhavantyaharāgame | rātryāgame pralīyante tatraivāvyaktasaṃjñake || || parastasmāttu bhāvo'nyo'vyakto'vyaktātsanātanaḥ | yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu naśyatsu na vinaśyati || || avyakto'kṣara ityuktastamāhuḥ paramāṃ gatim |
translation: All beings in the world, originating from the unmanifest to the manifest in the day, dissolve back into the unmanifest in the night. Indeed, separate from this, there exists another eternal unmanifest nature that does not perish nor is destroyed in all beings. That unmanifest, called indestructible, they call the supreme goal.

sloka: taddha tadvanaṃ nāma tadvanamityupāsitavyaṃ sa ya etadevaṃ vedābhihaina~ sarvāṇi bhūtāni saṃvāñchanti || ||
translation: That indeed, is named its forest , that forest is to be worshiped , one who knows this alone, along with the Vedas , such a one harmonizes with all beings .

sloka: tadyathā priyāya striyā striyāsaṃparṣvaktaḥ
translation: Just as addressed to a beloved woman by other women.

sloka: priyo hi jananinotyārthaṃ aham sa ca mam priyaḥ
translation: For sure, I am dear to them and they are dear to me.

sloka: pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ | kaṇḍanī codakumbhaśca badhyate yāstu vāhayan
translation: The five (pañca) items - the slinger, the grinding stone (cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ), the water pot (kaṇḍanī), and the pitcher (coda + kumbhaḥ) - are what a householder is obligated to use (badhyate) while giving (vāhayan), along with others (tu). So which ones (yāḥ) are those?

sloka: adhyāpanaṃ brahmayajñaḥ pitṛyajñastu tarpaṇam | homo daivo balirbhautī nṛyajño'tithipūjanam ||
translation:
Instructional ceremony toward Brahma,
the sacrifice to the ancestors is called tarpaṇa,
homa is the divine offering, while bali is for bhutas,
and the worship of human guests is atithi-pujan.

sloka: tadyadagnau juhoti sa devayajño yadbaliṅkaroti sa bhūtayajño yatpitṛbhyo dadāti sa pitṛyajño yatsvādhyāyamadhīyate sa brahmayajño yanmanuṣyebhyo dadāti sa manuṣyayajña iti tānetānyajñānaharahaḥ kurvīta
translation: The one who makes offerings into the fire is a performer of deva rituals, the one who offers oblations is a performer of bhuta rituals, the one who gives to the ancestors is a performer of pitr rituals, the one who studies (the Vedas) is a performer of brahma rituals. The one who gives to men is a performer of manushya rituals. These are the constituents of various rituals. One should always make an effort to do them thus.

sloka: tadvidhiprasaṅgena pañcamahāyajñānvidhatte
translation: Through dedicated adherence to the ritual script, he establishes the five great sacrifices.

sloka: pañca vā ete mahāyajñā: satati pratāyante satati saṃtiṣṭhante devayajña: pitṛyajño bhūtayajño manuṣyayajño brahmayajño iti iti
translation: Indeed, these five are great sacrifices: they are offered, they are established again and again. The sacrifice to the gods, the sacrifice to the ancestors, the sacrifice for living beings, the sacrifice for humans, and the sacrifice called Brahma.

sloka: tatra devayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yadagnau juhotyapi samidhaṃ taddevayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti puroḍāśādihavirmukhyaṃ tadalābhe samidhamapyagnau devānuddiśañjuhotīti yatso'yaṃ devayajñaḥ
translation: Here is described the identification of the deva-yajna sacrifice: it is when a fuel fragment is offered in the fire; that very identification is established through the chief component beginning with purodasa. When the fuel fragment is not present, the gods are invoked into the fire. That, indeed, is called the deva-yajna offering.

sloka: bhūtayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yadbhūtebhyo bali~ harati tadbhūtayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti
translation: The characteristic of the sacrifice to elements is giving away to the elements. That is the sacrifice to elements; it sustains.

sloka: manuṣyayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yadbrāhmaṇebhyo'nnaṃ dadāti tanmanuṣyayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti
translation: The definition of a human sacrifice is giving food to the brāhmaṇas; it (the human sacrifice) stands thus.

sloka: brahmayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yatsvādhyāyamadhīyītaikāmapyṛcaṃ yaju: sāmaṃ vā tadbrahmayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti svasyāsādhāraṇatvena pitṛpitāmahādiparamparayā prāptā vedaśākhā svādhyāyaḥ tatra vidyamānamṛgādīnāmanyatamamekamapi vākyamadhīyīteti yatso'yaṃ brahmayajñaḥ
translation: The definition of the sacrifice for Brahman is given: it is that which is studied through one's own understanding, whether it be the ṛcas of the Yajurveda or the Sāma Veda. This form of study has been passed down traditionally in the families, from father to grandfather and so on. In it, one should learn at least one mantra or a short passage by heart every day. The sacrifice for Brahman consists precisely of this.

sloka: devatoddeśena hi dravyatyāgo yāgaḥ| sa eva tyajyamānadravyasyāgnau prakṣepāddhoma ityucyate|
translation: The ritual (yāgaḥ) referred to as dravyatyāga, is defined as the casting (prakṣepāt) of a sacrificial object (tyajyamāna-dravyasya) into the fire (agnau), and is performed in honor of the deity (devatā-uddeśena). It is said that this is how it is called (iti ucyate).

sloka: darśapūrṇamāsayoścatvāra ṛtvijo'dhvaryurbrahmā hotāgnīdhra iti
translation: The four ṛtvijs, namely the adhvaryu, brahmā, hotā, and āgnīdhra, have completed the darśa and pūrṇamāsa rituals.

sloka: paśūnāṃ dravyahaviṣāmṛk‌sāmayajuṣāṃ tathā| ṛtvijāṃ dakṣiṇāyāśca saṃyogo yajña ucyate|| ||
translation: The combination of fees for the officiating priests and the sacrificial ingredients of animals is called Yajna.

sloka: ayam yajna vishvasya bhuvanasya nabheehi
translation: This universe's sacrificial ritual is named 'Nabhei'.

sloka: gṛhasthasya kriyātyāgo vratatyāgo vaṭorapi tapasvino grāmasevā bhikṣorindriyalolatā āśramāpasadā hyete khalvāśramaviḍambanāḥ devamāyāvimūḍhāṃstānupekṣetānukampayā
translation: For a householder, renouncing actions or vows, or even the observance of austerities in solitude, is just deceitful pretense of asceticism. One should be compassionate towards those who are deluded by divine illusion and act insensitively.

sloka: kṛttikāsu mahābhāge pāyasena sasarpiṣā| santarpya brāhmaṇānsādhū~llokānāpnotyanuttamān||
translation: Having offered oblations of payasam to the Krittikas, the fortunate one attains the highest destination by satisfying the worthy brahmanas.

sloka: ṛcāṃ tva: poṣamāste pupuṣvāngāyatraṃ tvo gāyati śakvarīṣu | brahmā tvo vadati jātavidyāṃ yajñasya mātrāṃ vi mimīta u tvaḥ ||
translation: To you, the nourisher of hymns, who was celebrated in the past, two are being sung in the sacred gatherings; to you, the eternal one, Brahma speaks; you have assumed the measure of the sacrificial rite.

sloka: avināśi tu tadviddhi yena sarvamidaṃ tatam | vināśamavyayasyāsya na kaścitkartumarhati || ||
translation: Indeed, understand that to be indestructible, by which all this is pervaded. No one can cause the destruction of what is unchanging and eternal.

sloka: tatko vṛtraḥ| megha iti nairuktāḥ | tvāṣṭro'sura ityaitihāsikāḥ | apāṃ ca jyotiṣaśca miśrībhāvakarmaṇo varṣakarma jāyate | tatropamārthena yuddhavarṇā bhavanti |
